  physical_appearance: This is a pair of batik pajama pants. It has a symmetrical pattern of bands featuring qilin and phoenix motifs. They are bordered by a border consisting of repeating geometric motifs.

  subject_terms_1: geometric motifs birds (motifs) cultural diffusion foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik

  subject_terms_3: Batik

  sgcool_label_text: The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern on this pair of batik pants (celanda).  The Chinese influence is evident on this piece
 particularly the mythical qilin and phoenix motifs
 and fretwork border which is a variant of the auspicious Chinese banji pattern.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942)
 the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time
 and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers
 centipedes and cloud motifs which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java
 before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a pair of batik pajama pants. It has a symmetrical pattern of bands featuring qilin and phoenix motifs. They are bordered by a border consisting of repeating geometric motifs.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: The batik cloth is carefully cut and joined in the middle to produce the symmetry of pattern on this pair of batik pants (celanda).  The Chinese influence is evident on this piece, particularly the mythical qilin and phoenix motifs, and fretwork border which is a variant of the auspicious Chinese banji pattern.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Soen King (1861-1942), the first in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her batiks feature the classic layout typical of her time, and are embellished with Chinese traditional motifs.  These motifs include lotus flowers, centipedes and cloud motifs which are rendered sensitively and imaginatively.  The combination of natural red and blue dyes on a cream ground is also characteristic of batiks made during this period in the north coast of Java, before the invention and widespread popularity of chemical dyes in batik sarongs by the late 19th century.  Oey Soen King’s pieces were all unsigned as signatures were not yet fashionable.
